docs.lead_paragraph: A study found that in places with more unevenness of income, life spans were shorter.

headline.main: Income Inequality: It’s Also Bad for Your Health
headline.print_headline: How Income Inequality Can Be Bad for Your Health

docs.abstract: The Upshot; research by University of Wisconsin Population Health Institute and Robert Wood Johnson Foundation finds evidence that suggests residents of communities with high income inequality are more likely to experience shorter live spans; study lends credence to theory that areas of higher income inequality will have less social cohesion and investment in education and public health.
docs.snippet: A study found that in places with more unevenness of income, life spans were shorter.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a state-federal partnership, 25 groups are part of a trial that would eventually reward health care providers if the conditions of their Medicaid patients improve.

headline.main: Pay for Performance Extends to Health Care in New York State Experiment
headline.print_headline: Pay for Performance Extends to Health Care in New York Test

docs.abstract: New York State prepares to initiate experimental Medicaid program that will eventually reward health care providers who improve conditions of their patients; state-federal partnership will include 25 high-volume practices that serve disadvantaged communities; will seek to incentivize closer monitoring and preventative care in order to reduce enormous public cost of hospital and emergency visits.
docs.snippet: In a state-federal partnership, 25 groups are part of a trial that would eventually reward health care providers if the conditions of their Medicaid patients improve.

docs.lead_paragraph:
ANDERSON--Jack R.

A leader in the hospital management and HMO industries, died on March 28, 2015 at his home in Vero Beach, FL. He was 90. He was President of the start-up hospital management company, Hospital Affiliates, Inc. from 1970 until its acquisition by INA Corporation in 1981, after which he led several public health care companies. He was Chairman of Horizon Health Corporation, Republic Health Corporation, United Dental Care, Inc., TakeCare, Inc. and FHP International Corporation. He was also a director of several other companies including Quality Inns, Inc., Navistar International Corporation, and Medical Care International, Inc., He was a member of the Board of Overseers of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University and a member of the Presidents' Circle for the National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering and the Institute of Medicine, Washington, DC. He authored "The Road to Recovery in 1976, a book outlining how to restore financial stability to unprofitable hospitals. Mr. Anderson was born February 14, 1925 in Mansfield, OH, where he was the youngest Eagle Scout at the time in Ohio in the Boy Scouts of America. He graduated Miami of Ohio University in 1947 and received his Masters from Columbia Business School in 1949. He served as an officer in the United States Navy during World War II, where he was assigned to a mine sweeper ship in the Pacific fleet. After returning from the War, while at Columbia, he married the love of his life, Rose-Marie Garcia Anderson, who survives him. She is a graduate of Hunter College and from Astoria, NY. He was employed at accounting and financial positions at Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner and Smith, Inc.; American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Inc.; Time Inc.; W.R. Grace & Company, Inc.; McCall Corporation and Reliance Group, Inc. In 1970 he became president and then chairman of Hospital Affiliates International, Inc. When that company was acquired by INA Corporation, he became chairman of The INA Health Care Group, Inc. which owned and managed hospitals on five continents, as well as health maintenance organizations and nursing homes in the United States. The CIGNA health plan resulted from the 1982 combination of the INA Corporation and Connecticut General Life Insurance Company. In addition to his wife, Rose-Marie, Mr. Anderson's survivors include three children, Gail Canizares, Neil Anderson, and Barbara McDonald, 11 grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Mr. Anderson travelled and read broadly, which furthered his interest in education. In 1994 he and his wife established the Anderson Foundation primarily to support efforts to improve K-12 education in America. Since that time they devoted considerable time and effort in pursuing that goal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Arizona Republican Governor Doug Ducey signed a law on Monday that requires doctors to tell women that drug-induced abortions can be reversed and that blocks the purchase of insurance on the Obamacare health exchange that includes abortion coverage.

headline.main: Arizona Governor Signs Bill Blocking Abortion Coverage Through Obamacare
headline.print_headline: Arizona Governor Signs Bill Blocking Abortion Coverage Through Obamacare

docs.snippet: Arizona Republican Governor Doug Ducey signed a law on Monday that requires doctors to tell women that drug-induced abortions can be reversed and that blocks the purchase of insurance on the Obamacare health exchange that includes abortion coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Doug Ducey signed a bill Monday that requires abortion providers in Arizona to tell women they can reverse the effects of a drug-induced abortion and also bars women from buying any health care plan through the federal marketplace that includes abortion coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: An apple a day doesn't necessarily keep the doctor away. That's according to proverb-busting research that found daily apple eaters had just as many doctor visits as those who ate fewer or no apples.

headline.main: An Apple a Day May Not Keep the Doctor Away, Study Says
headline.print_headline: An Apple a Day May Not Keep the Doctor Away, Study Says

docs.snippet: An apple a day doesn't necessarily keep the doctor away. That's according to proverb-busting research that found daily apple eaters had just as many doctor visits as those who ate fewer or no apples.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear a new challenge to President Barack Obama's healthcare law that took aim at a bureaucratic board labeled by some Republicans as a "death panel" because it was designed to cut Medicare costs.

headline.main: U.S. Supreme Court Rejects Obamacare 'Death Panel' Challenge
headline.print_headline: U.S. Supreme Court Rejects Obamacare 'Death Panel' Challenge

docs.snippet: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear a new challenge to President Barack Obama's healthcare law that took aim at a bureaucratic board labeled by some Republicans as a "death panel" because it was designed to cut Medicare costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers react to an Op-Ed essay about Angelina Jolie Pitt’s decision to have her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed.
docs.snippet: Readers react to an Op-Ed essay about Angelina Jolie Pitt’s decision to have her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act is costing taxpayers much less than expected, but that hasn’t deterred the prophets of disaster.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column criticizes distortion of facts by conservatives bent on portraying Affordable Care Act as economic disaster; holds whatever one's viewpoint, law is costing taxpayers far less than expected, and has not emerged as job-killer; argues conservative campaign belies an unsettling disregard for facts in politics, and unwillingness to concede arguments in face of overwhelming evidence.
docs.snippet: The Affordable Care Act is costing taxpayers much less than expected, but that hasn’t deterred the prophets of disaster.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: With the state close to issuing final regulations, supporters of the new program are concerned that some of its constraints will harm its effectiveness.

headline.main: New York State’s Medical Marijuana Rules Shaping Up as Unusually Restrictive
headline.print_headline: Medical Marijuana Regulations Are Shaping Up as Unusually Restrictive

docs.abstract: Supporters of impending medical marijuana program in New York State worry that measure is so strict that it will prevent many deserving patients from receiving the drug; Health Dept restrictions include only 10 qualifying conditions, would prevent smoking of the drug, and would limit consumption to only 5 medical brands.
docs.snippet: With the state close to issuing final regulations, supporters of the new program are concerned that some of its constraints will harm its effectiveness.
